title: Does Donald Trump have narcissistic personality disorder?  - Quora

response.answer_text: I've got my DSM-III (old) by me and looking online for some expert advice while I write this;   I'm just your humble answerer. First, there is a difference  between a narcissist and a person with NPD. People often get them confused.  I do too. My favorite narcissist joke is a narcissist says    "...Okay, enough about me... what  do you think about me?...."   Sorry - I think that's funny. Anyway; CRITERIA FOR NARCISSISTIC PERSONALITY DISORDER If you have narcissistic personality disorder, you may come across as conceited, boastful or pretentious. You often monopolize conversations. You may belittle or look down on people you perceive as inferior. You may feel a sense of entitlement — and when you don't receive special treatment, you may become impatient or angry. You may insist on having "the best" of everything — for instance, the best car, athletic club or medical care. (From the Mayo Clinic) Sound familiar? Many narcissists like to do things to impress others by making themselves look good externally. Narcissists uses people, objects, status, and/or accomplishments to represent the self, substituting for the perceived, inadequate “real” self.  To reach the level of a personality disorder, the behavior must be deeply ingrained, intense, displayed in a variety of situations, and maladaptive, causing long-term difficulties in personal relationships or in functioning in society.  Some Trump quotes; "I will be the greatest jobs president God ever created."  “On social media, I’m the one that’s beloved"  (comparing himself to Fox reporter Megyn Kelly)    One way to tell if a public figure is a narcissist is to see if criticisms (even minor ones) nearly always bring on an impulsive angry reaction. This is especially obvious in the Twitter age, when a fast reply is so easy.  It's one thing to sue magazines or organizations. But Trump turned his fury on a New York Times author who wrote that at the time Trump "only" had 250 million dollars. Trump sued him for five billion dollars, accusing the author of malice despite the fact that the author had three sources.  Trump, who was building the "best golf course in the world" on the Menie Estate in Balmedie, Aberdeenshire, was displeased when a homeowner near the golf course refused to sell him his house.  So without warning, the tycoon put a fence around the house and billed the owner for half the cost. The owner said: "There is no way I'm going to pay it. As far as I'm concerned it's just another attempt to intimidate and bully me "   Lack of empathy Trump contributes less to his Trump Charity foundation and even other contributors. Plus, he has a very stingy 401K plan for employees Donald Trump Operates Stingy 401(k) Plan for His Workers  http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20150731/BLOGS02/150729822/the-charities-donald-trump-gave-money-to-and-what-it-says-about-his-candidacy   Relationships largely superficial and exist for personal gain and to inflate self-esteem Trump has had three wives and several children, divorcing the second shortly before the prenup would have kicked in and given her more money. Are we ready for a first couple who met on a reality TV show? Who knows? Perhaps he loves all of them truly, madly, deeply, although his obvious infidelity with wife 1 with wife 2 caused a dustup in the entertainment magazines. I just can't help noticing that as he gets older, his wives get younger. I have no doubt that having a trophy wife is part of the brand.  So, does he have NPD? I'm not qualified to answer that... although it seems to me counterintuitive not to. However, he lives in a capitalist society that strongly values men (women, not so much) like him.     I think what makes narcissists so effective at this is their complete conviction that they are actually special and entitled. The rules are for someone else. It is always easier to fool others when you have already fooled yourself.   That to me is the real danger -- when the grits hit the fan, it will be someone else's fault. Is Donald Trump Actually a Narcissist? Therapists Weigh In!  EDIT....I don't think the DSM thinks of NPD as a disorder anymore, but as I said, I'm not qualified to say.

Is Trump A Narcissist? There’s little doubt that Trump is a narcissist. The bigger question is, is he higher up on the DSN’s list of dangerous personality disorders? Is he a sociopath or psychopath?    {Directly above is a paragraph from The Atlantic written in January 2018.} There are thousands, if not hundreds of thousands of articles written on Trump’s mental health. Experts from around the world agree he falls in the “dangerous personality disorder” range. This is something that needs to concern every single American, regardless of party. There is a reason his personality is considered dangerous and why he needs to be removed from office ASAP. Trump has exhibited 100 percent of the “most dangerous” personality traits. These traits are: Entitled And ArrogantNo EmpathyNo BoundariesPathological LiarsNeed To Control EverythingManipulativeGrandioseParanoidExploitiveNo RemorseBlameshiftersDon’t Take Responsibility For Their Words Or ActionsVengefulTrump’s list of lawsuits and alleged crimes are tremendous. The handful outlined below, displays he has no conscience, which falls in the range of the most criminal-mind behavior characteristic of all. He has stolen from others, exploits, intimidates and has no remorse in doing so. Trump University Case - He took $35K from students. Lawsuit lost where he had to return $25 million to students. {Theft and lying}Robert LiButti, a mob member, Trump had dealings and purchased nine luxury vehicles for him. Trump was fined $200K for keeping black employees away from LiButti’s table. The courts acknowledged he worked with crime families, but no “deals” found him “guilty” except of the aforementioned discrimination suit. {No boundaries}Tenants of Central Park South said Trump turned off heat and water to get them out of units. If they didn’t “listen,” he reportedly sued them for $150 million. { Bodily threats and intimidation}Trump paid undocumented Polish workers only $5/hour when building Trump Tower. His model agency used undocumented models, too. {Exploitive}Trump sued author of Trump Nation for $5 billion. Case thrown out, but attorneys found Trump lied more than 30 times. {Grandiose and manipulative}He also sued comedian Bill Maher, says Wikipedia: “In 2013 Trump sued comedian Bill Maher for $5 million for breach of contract. Maher had appeared on The Tonight Show with Jay Leno and had offered to pay $5 million to a charity if Trump produced his birth certificate to prove that Trump's mother had not mated with an orangutan. This was said by Maher in response to Trump having previously challenged Obama to produce his birth certificate, and offering $5 million payable to a charity of Obama's choice, if Obama produced his college applications, transcripts, and passport records.” The latter showcases who Trump just doesn’t care what kind of suit he gets into, he just likes to fight. And he’s fought in over 4,000 lawsuits, more than most on record. If he loses, and he has many big time losses, he proclaims to public he was actually the “winner.” {Delusional} Being a winner, is one of the signature traits of a “dangerous personality type,” as they are incapable to self-inspection. They cannot see what they’ve done wrong, and rarely take responsibility for doing wrong. So, this we know. Trump, with malicious intent, is willing to steal from others. We know he was willing to put tenants and others in bodily harm leaving them without heat or water. We know he deals with known criminals; American mob and reportedly the Russian mob. We know he will not pay his bills and has left local contractors “high and dry” without paying them. We know he will implement “slave labor” as he did with the Polish workers. We know he has demonstrated and was sued by not letting black employees near his mob friend. We also know he thinks of women as objects and has 19 different women who claim assault or, in two cases, rape. We know he regularly lies to the public as the president, and we know he calls reporters “stupid, losers” and “enemies of the people,” which is, in my opinion, an assault on the First Amendment. We know he, according to Washington Post, has lied to the world and American citizens over 6,400 times. Beyond disturbing. CNN won the right to have Acosta’s press pass restored, but the president, of course, says he’ll just leave the room if he doesn’t want to answer a question providing the question isn’t down the line he deems fit. This is chilling and just another manipulative tactic to control the media. It’s also very arrogant as the American people have the right to question and know what is happening in national and world wide politics. People who have personalities disturbances have an absolute need to control everything. If they cannot control it, they undermine it, do smear campaigns and will seek revenge upon the person or establishment, just as Trump stated when he was married to Marla Maples. He stated back then something of the sort, “If it takes me 10 years to get back at those who defy me, I will get revenge.” Marla Maples’ bodyguard reportedly killed himself 12 years after him working with Trump and it was stated he never could get past the Trump deal. Hmmmmm. People of America and the world have to be wary of Trump. He is dangerous and doesn’t care if he undermines the constitution, people in office or allies. He is a skilled manipulator, and is rocking the foundation of our democracy.

Does Donald Trump have NPD? Do many politicians? We badly need to understand a number of very important things about those we vote into such unparalleled power. Those somethings are all about Narcissistic Personality Disorder. People with this disorder number 6.2% of the general population (Stinson et al, USA, 2008) and are drawn to positions of power and prestige – politics being a favourite.  (Photo credit and great article on the subject at Psychologists believe Trump is showing signs of severe mental illness) People with this disorder all show consistent traits: DuplicityNarcissists have two personas – their “false self” – a charming and charismatic façade designed to garner support and admiration, and a “real” or “authentic” self that is highly toxic – wracked with deep self-loathing and chronically low self-esteem, motivated by a completely different set of drivers and emotions that normal people. They are the classic Jekyll & Hyde split personalities written about by Robert Louis Stevenson. Pathological LiarsGiven that their entire public personality is a lie, so they are pathological liars in every walk of life – and will lie about anything as required to reinforce their fake persona, to garner support and to hide the monster that lies beneath the mask. It is for this reason that they will lie on the campaign trail, making all kinds of promises that they feel an electorate will like and buy, anything to get them a vote and into power. They feel little if any self-generated obligation to fulfil these promises once in office, however. Lack of FeelingsAlthough this may sound unbelievable, narcissists are incapable of feeling certain emotions including empathy, compassion and love. Brain scans indicate that the part of the brain responsible for feeling these emotions, the amygdala, simply has not developed properly. To compensate for this, narcissists carefully study neurotypical people and the way they display such emotions, and then mimic them as best they when appropriate. Doing so convincingly is a key part of the charade. So whilst many people may care about a range of issues – global warming, ecological collapse, law & order, healthcare, education etc – the sad reality is that narcissists have no genuine feelings about these issues at all, hence the hollow promises and inaction. Sense of EntitlementNarcissists feel they deserve preferential treatment from others, from the system and from life in general. It is for this reason that they fiddle their expenses as much as they do, they are so predisposed to bribery and corruption, and feel that they above the law. Self InterestWe erroneously believe that politicians act in the best interests of society and the constituencies they represent. In reality a narcissist will act entirely in their own self interest, saying anything and doing anything to get themselves ahead. They have a distinct lack of moral compass when it comes to anything outside their own benefit. LabileNormal people usually have genuine and profound views. Narcissists do not, tailoring instead their apparent opinions to their current audience, saying anything that they think will win them greater popularity, influence, power, wealth etc in the moment. Their views will therefore vary from day to day, depending on who it is they are talking with (or at). Serial CheatingWhilst crippled by lack of self-esteem, narcissists desperately what is termed narcissistic supply, or fuel, to feed their weak sense of self. For many of them their apparent attractiveness to the opposite sex is a key indicator and boost to their fragile ego. As a result they are constantly on the hunt for new conquests. Their inability to feel any love, empathy or compassion, not to mention guilt or remorse, leaves with with little or no emotional bond to their current long-term partner – if they have any. MachiavellianPathological narcissists are Machiavellian to the core, regardless of how effective their “false self” is in persuading others to the contrary. They will manipulate facts, people and ideas to meet their objectives without a care in the world for any adverse impact that this might result in. Indeed, they harbour intense jealousy towards anyone who enjoys normality, joy or abundance (because they will never have these attributes), and derive sadistic enjoyment in causing other people pain. ChaosA narcissist is desperate to be significant, important and influential. In business and in their private lives, their ways result in chaos in the present and a trail of destruction in their wake stretching throughout their past. They are unable to hold themselves accountable however, dodging any kind of responsibility or blame. They will never apologise for the pain and anguish they cause but instead deflect it with a range of techniques. Psychometric Testing It is ridiculous that most people applying for any kind of job need to submit to psychometric tests, and yet the most powerful people in the country and not subjected to personality profiling before they are able to run for office. Sadly pathological narcissism is so endemic in politics throughout the world that we are rapidly moving into the point of no-return. It is easy to see how the vast majority of countries and federations have political systems that are so broken and corrupt that they are not fit for purpose. It is why humanity now faces so many existential threats, and with such political willpower to resolve the problems. Exceptions to the Rules Once in a while it is possible to encounter politicians who break the rules and exhibit normal range emotions. These are the ones driven by the greater good, and end up proposing sensible policies – some of which can appear radical. Jacinda Arden of New Zealand is one such example. Back to Donald Trump Is he a pathological narcissist? Over you to decide. But the next time you vote, please just consider whether you are contributing to the problem by putting such self-serving, back-scratching, toxic characters as pathological narcissists into power. The Direction of the World I’m passionate about the direction the world is going in, and fear people with Narcissistic Personality Disorder are leading us over the edge of a precipice. I write exclusively about NPD – please help me raise awareness and understanding about it by follow me here for a start.

Tens of thousands of psychologists and psychiatrists now say that Donald Trump himself has made it possible for them to determine his personality. His constant, often obsessive, daily tweeting give them the means by which they can see the consistency and extent of his narcissistic behaviors. Trump’s most lavish praise has always been for himself. He has sycophants who survive until the first disagreement and then they are booted out the door. His administration is rife with dissension and has the highest rate of turnover of any presidency. He cannot hold his own ship afloat. Others have to do it for him. He has no constancy of political opinion. Whatever works in his mind to allow him to “win” is what he espouses. Pro-this one day, anti-this the next. He is known to lack the ability to prepare for and be fully vetted on key points and doesn’t read daily briefings because he knows better than anyone about all issues. He also makes up his own foreign policy on the fly and former allies, like Germany, have now decided that with Trump as President the US is no longer to be trusted. His lack of empathy toward anyone he perceives to be “lesser”—and that pretty much includes everyone other than his small inner family circle—is well known. If you are not high status or helpful to him personally—in fortune, constituency, ability to work the system, etc.—your views and needs are entirely dismissible. His supporters have not yet had the pleasure of learning just how unstable their “stable genius” is. They may have an opportunity to learn that all too soon. There is already speculation that a loss in November will be too big a narcissistic injury for Trump to endure so that he cannot allow it to happen. If it appears he could lose, Trump will attempt to delay the election, claim it to be fraudulent, refuse to relinquish office, literally anything to continue as the “winner.” A narcissist will also never accept being found at fault or to blame. If there is a loss, Trump will loudly proclaim that it was everybody else’s fault but his own.

I think there is a measure of narcissism in every politician, including those who aren’t politicians like Trump. But the disorder requires a measure of functional impairment, and that can either be social, or in relationships, or in employment. Trump’s personal life appears pretty sound. People who know him say he’s charming. His former wife says he’s a wonderful guy. He has a great family, who appear to find him agreeable. It is hard to find people who say he has an explosive temperament, which in every NPD I’ve ever treated, is a common feature. Arguably, he’s been able to build a business and be successfully employed for decades, so it’s probably not a disorder, unless you are a dishonest observer. No functional impairment, or at least not to the level of treatment. Now, I don’t doubt he has narcissism, probably more than the average person. But that’s not a disability, and in politics, it’s a career requirement. If you want to start diagnosing people from a distance, let’s look at Hillary Clinton. The Paranoid Personality Disorder lists these traits: Doubt the commitment, loyalty, or trustworthiness of others, believing others are using or deceiving themAre reluctant to confide in others or reveal personal information due to a fear that the information will be used against themAre unforgiving and hold grudgesAre hypersensitive and take criticism poorlyRead hidden meanings in the innocent remarks or casual looks of othersPerceive attacks on their character that are not apparent to others; they generally react with anger and are quick to retaliateHave recurrent suspicions, without reason, that their spouses or lovers are being unfaithfulAre generally cold and distant in their relationships with others, and might become controlling and jealousCannot see their role in problems or conflicts and believe they are always rightHave difficulty relaxingAre hostile, stubborn, and argumentativeI wonder if she’s just as likely to be affected by paranoia as Trump is by narcissism. But again, although I’m a retired professional, I’m doing this at a distance with only public information at hand, and I am aware it’s pretty subjective.

trump has thrust the United States nearer to succumbing to be what is known as a "mafia state" to portray the sort of despotisms America and the world are witnessing leaping from the previous Soviet Union. The president’s close to home interests and the interests of the country have become isolated. trump has been open about his deference for Putin, the leader of a ground-breaking mafia state and indeed, regularly acts like a mafia don. But, under all the highfalutin bullshit and his inflated feeling of self-significance, there is a profound necessity for inordinate adulation and deference. With a slew of disconsolate relationships behind him and an absence of sympathy for other people, his veil rarely slips. Yet, when it does, exposed is brittle self-esteem that is powerless against the slightest analysis. For the most part, trump is despondent and bewildered when he's not given the exceptional favours or reverence he believes he deserves. He regularly discovers his relationships are unfulfilling, and others don't particularly enjoy being around him. trump becomes anxious or irate when he doesn’t receive unique treatment. He has significant interpersonal issues and effectively feels insulted if questioned. He responds with blistering fury or hatred and attempts to deprecate other individuals in order he appears unrivalled. Yet, the underlying factor is that he often feels insecure, often shameful, vulnerable and humiliated. He is fundamentally out for himself and will indecently request inconvenient favours as we've now become aware. He is known to have taken out several loans that he will never reimburse, and has burned through a multitude of long stretches of government time, grumbling or playing golf. He's a well off show off who is liberal with his "toys" as long as he gets to call the shots. Narcissists like trump are emotionally isolated and profoundly doubtful of others. Perceived dangers can trigger fierce rage while accomplishments can bolster sentiments of grandiosity. Although reliant on his devotees, he burns with a raging desire to be adulated and orders they feed his confirmation and idolisation. Nevertheless, when individuals react positively to trump, there are still threats. That is on the grounds that charm is a double-edged sword. It encourages both closeness and detachment. And as he appears progressively confident, trump turns out to be increasingly unconstrained. He feels free of restraints. Ideas stream. He believes he's invincible. This vitality and conviction further rouse his die-hard supporters. But the very hero-worship trump expects can have an erosive impact. He listens even less to expressions of caution and guidance. All things considered, he believes he is right even when others have their doubts. Instead of attempting to convince those who contradict him, he feels justified in overlooking them, thus creating further detachment. The outcome is glaring risk-taking that can prompt a crisis. In the political domain, there is no more a clearer case of this than trump. Regardless of any warm sentiments his charm may summon, he is typically not happy with his own emotions. He’ll listen only for the sort of information he is looking for and bruises easily when he is denied. He cannot tolerate criticism. Truth be told, he is abrasive with those who doubt him and even more violent with subordinates who have spine enough to confront him. He requires a gathering of yes-men and as the more independent players leave or are sacked, government progression turns into a specific, troubling issue. trump knows who he can use and is ruthlessly exploitative. For that reason, despite the fact that he believes without a doubt he has "star quality," he remains unlikable. Historically, narcissists in leadership have been confined to sales positions, where they use their persuasiveness and imagination to best effect. Nevertheless, a narcissistic leader, even the most profitable of them can self-destruct and lead their associations and the nation hideously off track.

Disclaimer: only a professional is qualified to diagnose Trump; only an official diagnosis can give a definitive answer to this question. Trump’s behaviour during the campaign and since the election gives us enough circumstantial evidence to suggest he might be. 1. Has a grandiose sense self-importance. 2. Is preoccupied with fantasies of unlimited success, power, brilliance, beauty, or ideal love. 3. Believes that he or she is "special" and unique and can only be understood by, or should associate with, other special or high-status people (or institutions). 4. Requires excessive admiration [regularly fishes for compliments, and is highly susceptible to flattery]. 5. Has a sense of entitlement. 6. Is interpersonally exploitative. 7. Lacks empathy: is unwilling [or, I would add, unable] to recognize or identify with the feelings and needs of others. 8. Is often envious of others or believes that others are envious of him or her. 9. Shows arrogant, haughty [rude and abusive] behaviors or attitudes. 6 Signs of Narcissism You May Not Know About How well does this list apply to Donald Trump? He certainly has a grandiose sense of self.He has made his fantasies of power and unlimited success real.He campaigned on the basis that he was special.He is excessively vain and defensive. He has demanded that the media not print unflattering pictures of him.He does not feel like obeying the same laws as apply to others.He has cheated his subcontractors and refused to pay taxes.His campaign showed he lacks empathy for others.He is clearly envious. He said that he would only accept the election results if he won; and now that he has won, he is behaving as though an election recount were a formal impeachment. He has argued that the liberal media were out to get him.Haughty, rude, and abusive? Search for Trump’s campaign. You will find more examples than you could shake the proverbial stick at.I cannot tell you whether Trump has narcissistic personality disorder. I can tell you that he behaves as if he does.

In order for a person to be diagnosed with narcissistic personality disorder (NPD) they must meet five or more of the following symptoms: Has a grandiose sense of self-importance (e.g., exaggerates achievements and talents, expects to be recognized as superior without commensurate achievements)Is preoccupied with fantasies of unlimited success, power, brilliance, beauty, or ideal loveBelieves that he or she is “special” and unique and can only be understood by, or should associate with, other special or high-status people (or institutions)Requires excessive admirationHas a very strong sense of entitlement, e.g., unreasonable expectations of especially favorable treatment or automatic compliance with his or her expectationsIs exploitative of others, e.g., takes advantage of others to achieve his or her own endsLacks empathy, e.g., is unwilling to recognize or identify with the feelings and needs of othersIs often envious of others or believes that others are envious of him or herRegularly shows arrogant, haughty behaviors or attitudesDonald Trump certainly appears to fit most if not all of the above criteria. Although given his position as president of the United States then some of those characteristics are valid. He will have a sense of self importance but that is understandable considering his current role. He is a very successful person as well and has accumulated huge wealth so it’s not fantasy for him. However these traits aren’t necessary for his position and aren’t just related to this. I have a feeling he would still have a huge sense of entitlement even if he had limited or no success. The rest of the traits are unrelated to his position and in fact will and do have a negative impact on how he handles his current role. It’s not a very good thing to be in charge of a country and lack empathy or to behave arrogantly towards others. Jealousy and envy of others will also have a detrimental impact on his leadership and will result in bad judgements and decision making. Also worth noting he will have shown these traits long before he was elected president but we can now see them more as he is more visible to us.

Well, this answer is going to be devoid of pop pseudo-psychology so it’s probably not going to be very popular. But there is very little chance that Donald Trump has Narcissistic Personality Disorder. NPD, contrary to folk belief, does not simply mean someone has a big ego, or is vain, or places an unhealthy importance on superficial traits like physical appearance and intelligence; someone can be vain, big-headed, and obsessed with looks or intelligence and not have NPD. NPD is a disorder, and that means someone with NPD is not only vain and preoccupied with looks and/or intelligence, grandiose in his or her expectation of treatment by others, and wildly delusional in many cases, but that these preoccupations and delusions impair the person’s ability to function normally around other people in society. It’s a very serious illness that gets trivialized whenever someone makes an NPD armchair diagnosis, which is exactly what’s going on here with Donald Trump. Donald Trump is a shallow liar, a 12 year old child trapped in a 70 year old man’s body, and an enormous embarrassment as president of our country. But he does not have NPD. Miraculously and unfortunately, this individual can function just fine, almost too well in some cases. Also, I would suggest you read about the Goldwater Rule before asking questions like this, Goldwater rule - Wikipedia Professional psychiatrists aren’t going to weigh in here.

I am amending my answer due to the mysteries of Quora’s question management. For purposes of the record, I’m leaving my original answer below, verbatim. Watch to see what happens. Original answer unchanged: The most useful answer seems to be, “Yes, and so what?” Was Barack Obama a narcissist? A thumbnail sketch might portray the US has having exchanged a passive-aggressive narcissist, Obama, for an active-aggressive narcissist, Trump. Narcissism is typical among psychological terms for its vague criteria and its undefinable boundaries. Allen Francis is the psychiatrist who led the team for Diagnostic and Statistical Manual IV. As editor of DSM 4 (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual for psychology), he wrote the definition of narcissistic personality disorder (NPD). Francis overtly hates Trump. However, he points out that (in his negative opinion) it doesn’t fit Trump because he lacks two of the five criteria. He even wrote a letter to the New York Times excoriating those who seek to gin up some psychological disqualifier to pull the rug out from under the Trump presidency by some extraordinary use of psychological jargon. The first link below is to a doc-to-doc analysis including great world leaders who did clearly suffer from psychiatric illnesses—Lincoln and Churchill. Francis seems to be trying intently to get the body politic and the media off their crusade to turn psychology into a martial art and then use it to flip Donald Trump on his butt and break his neck in the process. Misdiagnosing Trump: Doc-to-Doc with Allen Frances, MD Opinion | An Eminent Psychiatrist Demurs on Trump’s Mental State

And so was Obama, Bush, Clinton, Bush, Reagan, Carter, Ford, Nixon, Johnson, Kennedy, Eisenhower, Truman, Roosevelt, Hoover, Coolidge, Harding, Wilson, Taft, Roosevelt, McKinley, Cleveland, Harrison, Cleveland, Arthur, Garfield, Hayes, Grant, Johnson, Lincoln, Buchanan, Pierce, Filmore, Taylor, Polk, Tyler, Harrison, Buren, Jackson, Adams, Monroe, Madison, Jefferson, and Adams. I would also argue that Washington was a narcissist, based on his actions during the French-Indian War, but eventually gained a more sober, grounded opinion of himself by the time he reached the Presidency, as is evident in his attempts to refuse the position. Simply put: you do not say “Hey, I can convince a majority of voters that I am the best person to be running the Country, and I feel I can do a great job at it!” and not be, at least a bit, “narcissistic”. At least, according to the popular definition of the term. I’m not overly family with the nuts and bolts of text book psych, so as far as a clinical diagnosis? I don’t know, nor could I. And any professional who states they can make such a diagnoses based solely on media coverage, and never having met their subject, should have their professional licence brought into question.

He is a classic example of a narcissist. People like this have several things in common: They do not accept blame for wrongdoing. They will always blame their mistakes on others. You’ve seen Donnie the Connie do this time and time again.They think they are holier than God and believe they are the most intelligent people on earth. A narcissist will not interact with anybody who they believe is less intelligent than themselves, and in this case, that’s everyone but them. Hence narcissists typically have no friends.They absolutely have to be the center of attention. People who are narcisstic will do anything they possibly can to make sure they are front and center on anything. You’ve seen that occur with Trump (remember when he shoved a prime minister’s partner in order to be in the exact center of the photo with world leaders at the NATO conference?)Narcissists often appear charming and lovable. Trump showed this during the campaign. Of course, his actions since becoming President (illegally, i might add) have proved he is anything but.They hold grudges. Do I need to list the people Trump has criticized and mocked since he entered the race, and after becoming president? Narcissists also have zero tolerance for being criticized themselves. You’ve seen how he has acted any time someone has said something bad about him (and all those comments are well-deserved.That’s just a short list. Read this article if you want to know more: 10 Signs You Might Be a Narcissist

Ripping small children away from their parents is one of the most egregiously evil acts I can ever recall a US President making. He has shown many, many instances of being completely devoid of empathy besides this, too. He’s stiffed companies who’ve built his buildings for millions of dollars and he’s a relentless serial sexual assailant and abuser of women who actually has bragged about it publicly. My guess would be that he’s WAY up on the anti-social scale—possibly an out and out sociopath with many prominent and overtly narcissistic traits. Even my outrageously sexually predatory ex-husband was more covert than Trump is. But then, he’s highly intelligent and smart enough to know he’ll get more “wins” if he hides his predation. Trump, on the other hand, brags incessantly and glorifies his own lack of interest in literature. He barely reads and his vocabulary and sentence structure is on a 4th grade level. What’s terrifying to me is that roughly half of all Americans think he’s great. That’s so appalling that it literally scares me half to death. So I’ll be at a demonstration later this AM and I encourage anyone else who’s neurotypical and possesses a conscience to make the effort and show up to be counted. I agree with Christina Hepp below: he is a cancer and it’s spreading from the US to the rest of the world. But one thing at a time—let’s get those little kids in metal cages back to their frantic, grieving parents and show the Sociopath In Chief that he cannot get away with outrageously cruel tactics like this one.

No, no, NO. You cannot diagnose from afar. It doesn't matter how serious or obvious it looks. You cannot diagnose from afar. You could literally observe a suicidal, hallucinating person that makes disoriented moves and has crazy temper tantrums, but yet you still cannot diagnose from afar. Politics-wise, it doesn’t matter if it’s Hitler, Stalin, Gaddafi, Trump or whatnot. You cannot diagnose from afar. Diagnoses must be made by a trained clinical psychologist, in accordance to the guidelines from the DSM-V, ICD-10 or some other respectable manual of diagnosis. In all cases, it requires the psychologist to be directly interacting with and observing the patient. You cannot diagnose from afar. The American Psychiatric Association has a rule called the “Goldwater rule”, and it basically states that psychologists should only comment on what is supported by formal diagnostic examinations with regards to public figures. Once again, you cannot diagnose from afar. On a side-note, it is fine for psychological professionals to voice concerns over a public figure’s mental health and to recommend consultation. However, it stops there. If the individual rejects treatment, that’s that. You cannot diagnose from afar. I understand that this seems to be quite redundant on a single point, but really, this is an important issue. Too often, people will throw around mental illness as an instrument of insult or derogation, and frankly it’s rather unethical. It adds to the already tremendous stigma surrounding mental illness, and that can have greatly negative consequences. It’s an illness like all other illnesses, and must only be diagnosed by a professional in person. You cannot diagnose from afar. This really strikes a nerve in me, not only in politics but even in the interactions of daily life. Too often we’ll hear people informally diagnosing people, especially with illnesses such as depression, bipolar disorder or anorexia. It is well documented that the mere mention of a disorder can already lead to what’s called a “factitious psychological disorder”, where the subject unknowingly (or intentionally) creates psychological or physical symptoms for themselves, leading to great emotional strain. Imagine what a fake or incomplete diagnosis can do. Do not diagnose from afar. Most importantly, diagnoses are always made with treatment in mind; diagnoses inform the course of treatment, with the ultimate aim of helping the individual. If one does not have bona fide intentions for the wellbeing of the individual in question (which I am almost certain is the case with diagnosing Donald Trump), one should not be diagnosing anyone, especially not from afar. There are great implications for all diagnoses made in clinical psychology; let’s make them good implications, and not negative ones. We can start by taking mental illness seriously, and treating diagnoses as formal tools for the benefit of the individuals, so that they may get the help they need. Oh, and remember, you cannot diagnose from afar.

There’s overwhelming agreement that Trump is a world-class narcissist. There’s no need to revisit his deplorable traits/behaviors and the many criteria that fit him like a glove. But those facts alone don’t mean he has narcissistic personality disorder (NPD). I’ll explain. One of the indispensable elements of an NPD diagnosis is having the traits/behaviors cause great distress for the subject. In Trump’s case, his many appalling traits/behaviors have not interfered with achieving the life he wants. He’s wealthy, has somewhat functional family/business/social relationships, and a substantial career which happens to include holding the most powerful office on earth. In many respects, his narcissism has contributed to achieving his successes. He’s often his own worst enemy, his traits/behaviors make many others miserable, he leaves a wake of destruction and despair wherever he goes, and he may get us all blown up. And again, he’s a world-class narcissist. His life isn’t working for anyone else. But because it’s working for him, he doesn’t technically have NPD.

Whether Donald Trump has a specific psychiatric disorder is something that, granted, should best be left in the hands of professionals working in a clinal setting. But I don’t see any reason why laypeople should avoid trying to analyze his personality — it’s just that, in doing this, they shouldn’t pretend that they are making an actual clinical diagnosis. Rather, they should restrict themselves to saying things like “Donald Trump is a raging narcissist” or, maybe, “I wouldn’t be surprised to learn that Donald Trump was diagnosed with NPD,” or “I have a hunch that Donald Trump suffers from NPD.” The language of psychiatry has a specific clinal function, to be sure, and this should not be abused. But it is also a set of tools that can be used — and admittedly, abused — in making sense of the sphere of human interactions. This is often necessary, moreover, to defend oneself against certain malignant personality types. In politics, where it is a question of entrusting power to private individuals and elevating them to a special status that is almost if not altogether above the law, the common interest rests in exposing public figures to the greatest scrutiny, even if this might otherwise seem unfair. Indeed, very idea of psychological classification, one could argues, originates with Plato’s Republic, and has everything to do with politics. The psychiatric-clinical discourse, in contrast, is relatively new. And while it has its place in the world, it doesn’t have a monopoly on the profiling of personality and character.

Captain Corruption has all the symptoms: Narcissistic personality disorder — one of several types of personality disorders — is a mental condition in which people have an inflated sense of their own importance, a deep need for excessive attention and admiration, troubled relationships, and a lack of empathy for others. But behind this mask of extreme confidence lies a fragile self-esteem that's vulnerable to the slightest criticism. A narcissistic personality disorder causes problems in many areas of life, such as relationships, work, school or financial affairs. People with narcissistic personality disorder may be generally unhappy and disappointed when they're not given the special favors or admiration they believe they deserve. They may find their relationships unfulfilling, and others may not enjoy being around them. Treatment for narcissistic personality disorder centers around talk therapy (psychotherapy). Symptoms Signs and symptoms of narcissistic personality disorder and the severity of symptoms vary. People with the disorder can: Have an exaggerated sense of self-importanceHave a sense of entitlement and require constant, excessive admirationExpect to be recognized as superior even without achievements that warrant itExaggerate achievements and talentsBe preoccupied with fantasies about success, power, brilliance, beauty or the perfect mateBelieve they are superior and can only associate with equally special peopleMonopolize conversations and belittle or look down on people they perceive as inferiorExpect special favors and unquestioning compliance with their expectationsTake advantage of others to get what they wantHave an inability or unwillingness to recognize the needs and feelings of othersBe envious of others and believe others envy themBehave in an arrogant or haughty manner, coming across as conceited, boastful and pretentiousInsist on having the best of everything — for instance, the best car or officeAt the same time, people with narcissistic personality disorder have trouble handling anything they perceive as criticism, and they can: Become impatient or angry when they don't receive special treatmentHave significant interpersonal problems and easily feel slightedReact with rage or contempt and try to belittle the other person to make themselves appear superiorHave difficulty regulating emotions and behaviorExperience major problems dealing with stress and adapting to changeFeel depressed and moody because they fall short of perfectionHave secret feelings of insecurity, shame, vulnerability and humiliation

Yes. A personality disorder is a type of mental disorder in which you have a rigid and unhealthy pattern of thinking, functioning and behaving. A person with a personality disorder has trouble perceiving and relating to situations and to people. This causes significant problems and limitations in relationships, social encounters, work and school. In some cases, you may not realize that you have a personality disorder because your way of thinking and behaving seems natural to you. And you may blame others for the challenges you face. Personality disorders usually begin in the teenage years or early adulthood. There are many types of personality disorders. Some types may become less obvious throughout middle age. Specifically he is suffering from Narcissistic personality disorder: Description Persons with NPD are aggressive and boastful, overrate their performance, and blame others for their setbacks; current editions of DSM portray them as arrogant, entitled, exploitative, embedded in fantasies of grandeur, self-centered, and charming but emotionally unavailable. This portrayal of persons with NPD conveys only a minimal sense of their self-experience and misses their complexity. Narcissistic Personality Disorder: Rethinking What We Know Symptoms Belief that you're special and more important than others Fantasies about power, success and attractiveness Failure to recognize others' needs and feelings Exaggeration of achievements or talents Expectation of constant praise and admiration Arrogance Unreasonable expectations of favors and advantages, often taking advantage of others Envy of others or belief that others envy you http://www.mayoclinic.org/diseas... Causes It's not known what causes narcissistic personality disorder. As with other mental disorders, the cause is likely complex. Narcissistic personality disorder may be linked to: Mismatches in parent-child relationships with either excessive pampering or excessive criticism Genetics or psychobiology — the connection between the brain and behavior and thinking Narcissistic personality disorder
